That cross in the distance was installed there, a few centuries after the Colosseum was built. Because during the construction of the Colosseum, Rome was a pagan believer, and Christians were fed to the lions. <b>The Colosseum Rome, Italy<b>

Taken near the north side of the Colosseum as evening fell. This area is close to where the colossal statue of Nero is, and just across the street to the entrance of Rome's "Colosseo" MRT station. My last shot of the Colosseum, before taking the subway train. Lumina and Umbra are latin words, which translates to light and shade in English. I originally had the title of "Light and Shade" -- and just wanted to see something different. <b>The Colosseum - North Side Rome, Italy<b>

Its not always easy to leave...

Time to settle down a bit and send these from Rome. I think these trips are getting hectic, trying to go back to my list, and figuring out whom I missed out. I've already sent some, from Venice, Florence and Pisa. Sent some from within the walls of the Vatican. Now I'm checking who didn't get one yet. Its a little stressful, but sending out a postcard is a better souvenirgift than chocolates - they last forever, and besides, you don't have to carry it home. Of course, I only send to some to friends and relatives whose addresses I have kept. So if we're good friends, and you did not get one, you probably did not give me your address or your area's postal office is lousy. :-) <b>Postcards from Rome, Italy <b>

italy rome roma pen writing cards europa europe italia post roman basilica postcard structures stamp colosseum souvenir trevifountain gift postcards present postal stpeterssquare piazzanavona sistinechapel colosseo stpetersbasilica thespanishsteps tiberriver thecolosseum fountainoffourrivers castelsaintangelo viadeconsolacion

And you marveled at the modern day stadiums -- its size and grandeur. Wait till you see this in person. This may not have the capacity, but -- does a stadium with a capacity of 50,000, with good acoustical design -- built almost 2,000 years ago (twenty centuries) amaze you? Built in the late 1st century AD, this huge stadium has a capacity of over 50,000. One of the most famous achievements of Roman engineering and an elegant work of Roman architecture. This elliptical amphitheater is known also as the Colosseu, Colosseum, Roman Coliseum, Flavian Amphitheater, Amphitheatrum Flavium, Anfiteatro Flavio. The manpower used to build it were from slaves and prisoners of the Roman Empire. Depending on which century you're looking at it, it was the site of great spectacle. It was used for dramas, executions, animal hunts, and other gatherings. In the early centuries, it was used many times to feed Christians to Lions and wild beasts. Time will soon change. When the Christian church rose to power, and adopted by the Roman Empire, Christian executions stopped -- and the Popes turned its power against those responsible for the scientific revolution. IN the early days of the medieval period, the Colosseum was predominantly used for religious activities and housing. And ironically enough, the stones and bricks used in the Colosseum -- where early Christians were executed -- were used in part to build the structures of Vatican City. <b>The Colosseum Rome, Italy<b>

The man responsible for the greatest turning point of Early Christianity. In the year 312 AD, after winning a battle against another Emperor(at that time there were several emperors of Rome), he gradually led to the rise of Christianity. For years before that, Christians faced martyrdom, persecution and executions. Following Constantine's rule, Christianity rose to become the Roman Empire's official religion. Once you're walking the upper halls of the Colosseum, near the west side, you can have a good view of one of the largest arcs that the Romans built. The inscriptions read: IMP · CAES · FL · CONSTANTINO · MAXIMO · P · F · AVGUSTO · S · P · Q · R · QVOD · INSTINCTV · DIVINITATIS · MENTIS · MAGNITVDINE · CVM · EXERCITV · SVO · TAM · DE · TYRANNO · QVAM · DE · OMNI · EIVS · FACTIONE · VNO · TEMPORE · IVSTIS · REM-PVBLICAM · VLTVS · EST · ARMIS · ARCVM · TRIVMPHIS · INSIGNEM · DICAVIT In English: To the Emperor Caesar Flavius Constantinus, the greatest, pious, and blessed Augustus: because he, inspired by the divine, and by the greatness of his mind, has delivered the state from the tyrant and all of his followers at the same time, with his army and just force of arms, the Senate and People of Rome have dedicated this arch, decorated with triumphs. This arch had been here for around 1,700 years. And would later be a model for the creation of another great arc - in France - Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel - yes, that arc in front of the Louvre. Shot taken from the Colosseum's second level. <b>Arch of Constantine Rome, Italy<b>

The underground prison, the dungeons, the viewing deck of the people of Rome, the Senators, the Emperors, the bloodbath, the massacre -- all that remains is this fearful symmetery. West side of the Colosseum, Shot taken from the east side. Note that the Colosseum is elliptical, with its major axis almost aligns from East to West. And I thought with the dull colors, I'll just have this in BW. <b>Colosseo Roma, Italia<b>
